article.title: The redshift evolution of major merger triggering of luminous AGN: a slight enhancement at z$âˆ¼$2

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 depict about the AGN selected for this study (red points) compared to the total sample (blue points)?
choices: The selected AGN have a narrower redshift range than the total sample.
The selected AGN have a narrower X-ray luminosity range than the total sample.
The selected AGN are a representative subset of the total sample across the chosen redshift and X-ray luminosity range.
The selected AGN are mostly concentrated at the lower end of the X-ray luminosity range of the total sample.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from the projected histograms in Figure 2, comparing the distribution of AGN hosts (red) and control galaxies (blue) in stellar mass and redshift?
choices: AGN hosts and control galaxies have similar stellar mass distributions.
AGN hosts have a significantly higher average redshift than control galaxies.
The matching process resulted in a very close match in redshift between AGN hosts and control galaxies.
Control galaxies were selected to have a narrower range of stellar masses than AGN hosts.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main purpose of adding stars to the control galaxies as shown in Figure 3?
choices: To simulate the gravitational lensing effect of an AGN on its host galaxy.
To artificially increase the brightness of control galaxies to match AGN hosts.
To mimic the obscuring effect of a bright AGN on the underlying structure of its host galaxy.
To test the accuracy of GALFIT in differentiating between stars and galaxies at high redshift.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of using Equation 1 in this study?
choices: To estimate the redshift of AGN hosts based on their black hole mass.
To derive the mass of the central bulge of a galaxy from its total stellar mass.
To estimate the black hole mass of AGN based on the velocity dispersion of their host galaxies.
To estimate the mass of AGN host galaxies using their SMBH mass and a known scaling relation.
